channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran’s President Is Squeezed by Opposition Leader’s Demand for a Trial
item.description: The request by the opposition leader, Mehdi Karroubi, who is under house arrest, highlighted a deepening rift in Iran’s reformist wing.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani on Thursday. The president has promised to end house arrest for Mehdi Karroubi and two other leaders of the reformist Green Movement.

item.title: Pakistan’s Premier Leaves the Country Amid Panama Papers Scandal
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif left Pakistan to receive medical treatment in London in the middle of an unfolding scandal over his family’s offshore wealth.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, right, in Islamabad last month. Mr. Sharif traveled to London on Wednesday for medical treatment.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japan’s Kyushu Island, Killing at Least 3
item.description: The quake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 6.4, damaged buildings, knocked out power and killed at least three people, according to Japanese news media.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: A collapsed wall in Mashiki, Kumamoto Prefecture, after a strong earthquake struck Japan on Thursday.

item.title: After Europe and Turkey Strike a Deal, Fears Grow That Migrants Will Turn to Italy
item.description: With an agreement reached to curb the flow of refugees into Greece, there is new focus on a dangerous sea route from Libya to Italy.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman in Siracusa, Italy, gave money to an African migrant outside a church on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Parliament Approves a New Prime Minister
item.description: Volodymyr B. Groysman, an ally of the president, replaced Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk in the most significant shuffle of the country’s senior leadership since a revolution two years ago.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, the former Ukrainian prime minister, leaving a session of Parliament in Kiev on Thursday.

item.title: Belgian Court Lengthens Prison Term of Extremist Preacher
item.description: The sentence for Khalid Zerkani, convicted of recruiting young men to join the jihadist fight in Syria, was increased from 12 years to 15.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Russia’s Vulnerable Side Is at Fore in Putin’s Call-In Show
item.description: Domestic concerns, not international swaggering, dominated the choreographed call-in show, amid a second, punishing year of recession in Russia.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Belgian Court Lengthens Prison Term of Extremist Preacher
item.description: The sentence for Khalid Zerkani, convicted of recruiting young men to join the jihadist fight in Syria, was increased from 12 years to 15.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Memo From Germany: Merkel, Accused of Betraying Core Values, Faces a Balancing Act With Turkey
item.description: The political costs of doing business with the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, are becoming clearer by the week for the chancellor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany after a news conference in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: Poll of British Muslims Reveals Startling Views, but Some Question Methodology
item.description: A new poll of British Muslims revealed attitudes on homosexuality and terrorism sharply out of step with broader public opinion.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Muslim men at the Baitul Futuh Mosque in London. A new poll revealed views among Britain’s largest religious minority that differed from the greater population’s.

item.title: Chacha the Chimp Escapes Japanese Zoo, Then Takes a Fall
item.description: A video shows the capture of a chimpanzee two hours after he fled from a zoo in northern Japan.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Letter From Africa: Revelations From Panama Papers Are Old News for Africans
item.description: Many in Africa have long known that billions of dollars are being spirited away to tax havens every year, making their lives even more precarious.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Khulubuse Zuma, a nephew of President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, is among the the African political elites cited in the Panama Papers.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japan’s Kyushu Island, Killing at Least 3
item.description: The quake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 6.4, damaged buildings, knocked out power and killed at least three people, according to Japanese news media.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: A collapsed wall in Mashiki, Kumamoto Prefecture, after a strong earthquake struck Japan on Thursday.

item.title: Escaped Chimpanzee Captured in Japan
item.description: An male chimpanzee who had escaped from a local zoo was captured by city officials on Thursday in northern Japan. Zoo officials said the primate was not hurt during his capture.

item.title: Russian Aircraft Near U.S. Ship
item.description: The White House said on Wednesday that Russia had violated professional military norms over the Baltic Sea when one of its planes flew “dangerously close” to an American ship and a Polish aircraft.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Transit: Cuban Law on Cruises Prompts a Protest
item.description: Protesters outside Carnival Corporation headquarters demonstrated against a Cuban law that prohibits those born in the country from traveling by sea.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ELAINE GLUSAC
item.media:credit: Carl Juste/Miami Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A protester at a rally in Doral, Fla. on Tuesday.

item.title: Canadian Prime Minister Seeks to Legalize Physician-Assisted Suicide
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has introduced legislation to address the legal void left after Canada’s Supreme Court overturned a ban on doctor-assisted death.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has said his support for doctor-assisted death was informed by the last days of his father, former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

item.title: IHT Retrospective Blog: 1966: Iraqi President Killed in Crash
item.description: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Iraqi president is killed in a helicopter crash in 1966.
item.dc:creator: INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Europe, in Wake of Attacks, Votes to Collect Air Passenger Data
item.description: Lawmakers approved the measure, which is backed by the United States, to establish a continentwide system to share information on travelers.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A security agent screened a passenger’s travel documents in Brussels last week. The data about travelers that the European Union hopes to begin sharing includes names, travel dates, itineraries and payment methods.

item.title: Europe’s Privacy Watchdogs Call for Changes to U.S. Data-Transfer Deal
item.description: The region’s national regulators say the so-called Privacy Shield agreement does not sufficiently protect their citizens’ rights.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We believe there’s still work to do,” Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin, France’s data protection chief, who also heads a Pan-European regulatory privacy group, said on Wednesday.
